awd_titl_txt: Exploring Transfer Between Computing and Algebra and Its Effects on Mathematics Pedagogy and Self-efficacy in Computing Teachers
awd_abstract_narration:
As computing has become such an integral part of the STEM disciplines, the STEM+Computing Partnership (STEM+C) program advances the integration of computational approaches in STEM teaching and learning and how this integration can improve STEM learning, engagement, persistence, and computational thinking. Computational Thinking (CT) is a relatively new educational focus and a clear need for learners as a 21st century skill. This proposal tackles this challenging new area at the high school level by leveraging a curriculum designed to integrate mathematics and computing to improve learning in both to understand how learning these two subjects together can lead to improvement in both students' understanding and teachers' perceptions of and knowledge about these subjects. Understanding the ways that learning mathematics impacts learning computing and vice-versa is an important research goal. Learning computing is vital for preparing today's students for the many job opportunities available in this area. In addition, the project will train over 600 teachers in diverse schools in using this curriculum, leading to a strong possible impact on improving learning and retention in STEM and computing.

The project will investigate the ways that learning mathematics and programming mutually influence each other. The project uses the Bootstrap curriculum in which students program videogames. Bootstrap is a function-based computing language that targets important algebraic concepts. The curriculum is designed around key mathematical practice standards to help teachers incorporate it into their existing courses. The research on student learning will focus on: 1) which of the intended concepts transfer from Bootstrap to algebra, 2) the type of scaffolding that best supports this transfer, and 3) the aspects of the curriculum that contribute to that transfer. The research on teachers will focus on: 1) the effect of using Bootstrap on teacher perceptions of connections between math and computing, 2) the aspects of the curriculum's pedagogical style and the professional development provided that affect teachers skill and confidence level teaching computing, and 3) possible differential effects for teachers whose primary area was mathematics or computing prior to using Bootstrap. In addition to the 200 teachers the project team has already trained, they will train an additional 600 teachers over the course of the project. During the project, they will collect teacher data from at least 100 teachers in each year for Years 2 and 3 of the project and student data from 20 of those teachers' classes.

por.por_cntn:
Bootstrap is a curricular project that aims to integrate introductory
computing into existing middle- and high-school courses. This project
studied the effectiveness of Bootstrap with both teachers and
students, with a significant focus on transfer, the application of
knowledge and skills in one context to problems in another
context. For students, we looked at their transfer of content and practices
learned in Bootstrap to standard Algebra problems. For teachers, we
looked at their transfer of knowledge and pedagogic practices from
math into working with computing. Throughout the project period, we
refined our materials and professional-development workshops to
reflect what we were learning.

The intellectual merit of this project lay in its unique integration
of math and computing. Both mathematics and computing share a common
foundation around algebraic functions. In theory, this enables using
computing to teach about algebraic functions within contexts that
students recognize, which would simultaneously reinforce math learning
and instruction.  The project focused on the Bootstrap:Algebra
curriculum, in which students create a videogame by solving a series
of word problems, each carefully designed to exercise a new concept
that exists in both math and computing. Project findings showed that
students do improve performance on certain standard algebra questions
(specifically, word problems and function composition problems) after
working with Bootstrap. Findings also showed that teachers see the
connections between computing and math through Bootstrap, at the level
of both content and practice standards for mathematics.

The broader impact of this project took several forms. We offered
professional development to 1388 teachers (each attending a 3-day
workshop, all in-person with the exception of roughly 80 teachers who
trained online during COVID). At least 50,000 students accessed
curricular activities through one of our programming platforms. Longer
term, this project led to heavily revised materials for professional
development and classrooms. The new materials (a) are designed to be
flexibly combined to support different or smaller projects, (b) make use of
established pedagogic practices from math, (c) are provided in Google
Docs that teachers can copy and modify to create their own class
notes, and (d) come with interactive slides (using PearDeck) to
facilitate using them for remote instruction.

Since this project began, all 50 states have published plans for
including computer science in their K-12 curricula. Two-thirds of the
states have new computer science standards either adopted or in active
development. Many states and districts are considering integrating
computing into existing middle-school courses, partly as a way of
working within resource constraints regarding staffing, budgets, and
time in the curriculum. Bootstrap has emerged from this project with
professional development models and teaching materials that are ready
for scaling; this has potential for significant and broad impact in
the near-term as states implement their computing-education goals.
